figure_1.title: Figure 1. Paradigm Change from the clinical examination of the optic disc to the clinical evaluation of the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues using OCT.
figure_1.caption: (Left) Color photo of a non-human primate (NHP) control (N – nasal; T- temporal; S – superior; I – inferior). As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4). The clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” are based on the clinical disc margin which lacks a consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation (see Introduction). The clinical disc margin is therefore inconsistently assigned by clinicians (note open versus closed white dots) which undermines the anatomic foundation for concepts such as disc “size”, “shape”, “tilt”, “torsion” and the “gamma” region. (Center) Vitreal (lower) and retrobulbar (upper) views of an 8 mm trephined NHP ONH tissue specimen from the same eye. Note the dramatic increase in the size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath insertions relative to the size of the clinical “disc”. We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).

figure_2.title: Figure 2. Paradigm change from the clinical disc margin (CDM) to OCT defined ONH neural canal and peri-neural canal (pNC) regions and tissues.
figure_2.caption: (A) The clinical “optic disc” (or “papilla”) and “peripapillary” regions are defined relative to the clinical disc margin (Figure 1). (B) We propose that OCT evaluation of the ONH tissues should be organized relative to the OCT-detected neural canal and the Foveal-BMO axis (see Figures 3 and 4). We define the neural canal to be the connective tissue pathway through the choroid and sclera through which the RGC axon bundles achieve the retrolaminar orbital optic nerve. The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT. ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.

figure_3.title: Figure 3. OCT neural canal and peri-neural canal (pNC) anatomic landmarks in a representative control (left) and highly myopic (right) eye.
figure_3.caption: Descriptions of Panels A through H are the same for both the healthy control and highly myopic eyes. (A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4). The single heavy green line depicts the location of the representative B-scan shown in (B) (superior-nasal (SN) left and inferior-temporal (IT), right). (C) The 3D point cloud of all segmented OCT landmark points which are segmented within the Panel B B-scan in (D). (E) The ASCO (blue dots) and pNC anterior scleral canal surface (yellow dots) point cloud which is shown within an individual B-scan in Panel (F). See the Methods section for a detailed description of this anatomy and its segmentation.

figure_4.title: Figure 4. Paradigm change to image acquisition and pPole parameter regionalization relative to the OCT-detected, Foveal–BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis.
figure_4.caption: The OCT FoBMO axis estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe. FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14. FoBMO 30° ONH sectors from a representative study eye (FDA232) are shown. FoBMO 30° (clock-hour) or Garway-Heath regions, (not shown) can also be assigned post-acquisition to fundus photos by colocalizing them to the infrared (IR) fundus image acquired at the time of OCT A-scan acquisition. Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging. Using the FoBMO axis for orientation means FoBMO sectors are anatomically consistent relative to the estimated temporal raphe in a given study eye (and then among all study eyes) regardless of the amount of cyclotorsion present on the day of imaging. Also see Figures 11, 12 and 14. (S: superior; SN: superior-nasal; NS: nasal-superior; N: nasal; NI: nasal-inferior; IN: inferior-nasal; I: inferior; IT: inferior-temporal; TI: temporal-inferior; T: temporal; TS: temporal-superior; ST: superior-temporal

figure_5.title: Figure 5. Peri-neural canal scleral bowing – scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS) measured in three segments relative to the ASCO within each B-scan.
figure_5.caption: The pNC anterior scleral surface was fitted using a trilinear model and pNC-SB-SS was calculated for three juxta-canalicular anterior scleral segments (0-300 microns), (300 to 700 microns) and (700 to 1000 microns) measured relative to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) within the ASCO reference plane after projection of these measurement points to the anterior scleral surface. Within each B-scan, the slope direction for each anterior scleral segment was determined by the position of its proximal measurement point relative to its distal measurement point (the position of the distal measurement point for each segment is depicted by the segment-specific, colored dotted lines). By convention, “outward” pNC-SB-SS (as shown above) was defined to be present when the proximal end of a segment was “below” its distal end and its sign was defined to be positive (+). “Inward” pNC-SB-SS (not shown) was defined to be present when the proximal end of a segment was “above” the distal end and its sign was defined to be negative (−). Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.

figure_6.title: Figure 6. Peri-neural canal scleral bowing – ASCO Depth relative to a 1700 μm peri-neural canal scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) in 2D (above) and in 3D (below).
figure_6.caption: A 1700 μm perineural canal scleral reference plane (pNC-Scleral1700) was defined by the plane that best fit the anterior scleral surface points at a distance 1700 μm away from the ASCO centroid (measured within the ASCO reference plane). ASCO depth was defined at each ASCO point as the minimum distance to pNC-Scleral1700 reference plane (negative (−) when above the plane and positive (+) when below). Global pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined to be the average of the 48 individual ASCO point depth values. Sectoral pNC-SB-ASCOD was calculated as the average depth value of the four ASCO points within each sector, (24 radial B-scans, each containing 2 ASCO points, yield 48 ASCO measurement points distributed over twelve 30° s sectors).

figure_7.title: Figure 7. Perineural canal choroidal thickness (pNC-CT) at six distances from the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) within the ASCO reference plane.
figure_7.caption: Within the 3D point cloud of segmented points from each OCT ONH data set, (Figure 3), Bruch’s membrane and the anterior scleral surface points were interpolated using b-splines. pNC-CT was assessed in microns at six distances (vertical blue dotted lines) from the ASCO, measured within the ASCO reference plane, (horizontal blue dotted line). Each measurement distance was projected from the ASCO to the anterior sclera surface (yellow dots). At each anterior scleral measurement point pNC-CT was defined by the minimum distance to the posterior surface of Bruch’s membrane (red arrows) (pNC-CT 100, pNC-CT 300, pNC-CT 500, pNC-CT 700, pNC-CT 900, and pNC-CT 1100, respectively). To simplify data presentation, we concentrate on pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points (where they approximate the measurement of pNC-SS (see Figure 5). This strategy does not measure choroidal thickness between the pNC-CT 100 measurement point and BMO (transparent red). This region of the choroid can be the site of extensive neural canal remodeling and choroidal thinning and/or atrophy in myopic eyes.

figure_8.title: Figure 8. Eye-specific, global pNC-SB- data (above) and pNC-CT data (below) by age and clinical cohort.
figure_8.caption: Data for three representative pNC-CT measurement locations are chosen to approximate the pNC-SB data locations above. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.

figure_9.title: Figure 9. Mean Sectoral pNC-SB is increased and mean sectoral pNC-CT is decreased in highly myopic (right) compared to control (left)) eyes and these effects most commonly achieved significance within the inferior sectors.
figure_9.caption: All 30° sectoral data are in right eye, FoBMO orientation (upper left panel). pNC-SB-SS (0-300), (300-700), and (700–1000) radial measurement segments (top) and pNC-CT (300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points) (bottom) are schematically presented in three concentric rings. For either the control or highly myopic eye data, (treated separately), for each parameter, at each radial measurement location, the three contiguous sectors with the highest mean value are denoted with bold purple font and the three with the lowest mean values are denoted with bold orange font. The three highest bowing or thickest choroidal sectors are significantly different from the lowest bowing or thinnest choroid sectors (p < 0.0002 for all comparisons, (GEEGLM model adjusting for age, axial length and ASCO area). pNC-SB (for all parameters) was greatest and pNC-CT was thinnest within the temporal and inferior temporal sectors of the control eyes and were thinnest within the temporal inferior, inferior temporal, inferior and inferior-nasal sectors of the highly myopic eyes. Within a second GEEGLM model, adjusted in the same manner, statistically significant (p < 0.05) highly myopic versus control eye differences (red asterisk) in the three contiguous minimum (orange) and maximum (purple) mean sectoral values achieved statistical significance for the majority of pNC-SB parameters and for the three thinnest pNC-CT sectors at the 1100 μm measurement point (inferior temporal sectors, bottom right panel). Taken together these data together suggest that while the sectoral locations of maximum pNC-SB and minimum pNC-CT do not perfectly overlap, highly myopic versus control eye differences in both phenomenon most commonly achieved significance within the inferior sectors.

figure_11.title: Figure 11. Clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, FoBMO visualization of pNC-SB and pNC-CT data for the healthy control (upper) and highly myopic (lower) eyes shown in Figure 3.
figure_11.caption: (A) BMO, ASCO and the OCT FoBMO axis are projected onto the fundus photo of each eye by colocalizing the photo to the infrared (IR) fundus image acquired at the time of OCT A-scan acquisition. FoBMO orientation of the data is achieved by rotating the photo (8° counter clock-wise above and 10° clockwise below) so that the FoBMO axis, rather than the Acquired Image Frame ((AIF) - Blue outline –Figure 4), establishes the Nasal-Temporal and Superior-Inferior axes (shown for the healthy control eye, above, red dotted lines). (B) pNC-SB-ASCOD data for each eye schematically presented in eye-specific, (left eye above and right eye, below) FoBMO orientation. (C) pNC-SB-SS data for the inner (0-300), middle (300-700) and outer (700-1000) measurement segments presented schematically in FoBMO orientation. (D) Continuously plotted pNC-SB-SS data in FoBMO orientation. (E) and (F) pNC-CT data presented schematically (E) and continuously (F) relative to the FoBMO axis. Note that while the sectoral differences in pNC-CT data are modest for the control eye (upper) and substantial for the highly myopic eye (lower), by inspection of the sectoral values, the inferior temporal regions demonstrate the greatest amount of pNC-SB and the thinnest pNC-CT for both the control and highly myopic eye.

figure_12.title: Figure 12. A conceptual framework for clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, structural abnormality detection in highly myopic eyes relative to non-highly myopic normative data bases (NDBs).
figure_12.caption: Data in this figure are representative, only, in that the MRW data (right), pNC-SB and pNC-CT data (center) and the pPole RGC and GCL data (left) have been compiled from different eyes. Structural abnormality data begin with representative ONH minimum rim width (MRW) data (far right) in which FoBMO 30°sectoral OCT rim anatomy is shown along with its MRW measurement (color coded to flag “borderline” (yellow < 5th percentile of the NDB) or red (< 1st percentile of the NDB) sectors. pNC-CT and pNC-SB-SS (middle) and (middle right) columns) are from the highly myopic study eye shown in Figures 3 and 11 and depict their relationship to the normative values for these parameters that we have reported in previous studies. As can be seen from these plots, pNC-SB-SS is increased beyond the non-highly myopic normative range within the inferior temporal sectors and pNC-CT is “Borderline” thinned within the same sectors. pPole RNFLT) (middle left), and pPole Ganglion Cell Layer (GCL) (thickness) (far left) upper row data are continuous thickness or slope maps and bottom row data are continuous NDB percentile maps (red, yellow and green pixels as defined for MRW measurement arrows – far right). Though representative, these data serve illustrate, the OCT characterization of myopic structural alteration in a given eye.

figure_13.title: Figure 13. Thirteen international clinical sites will collaborate through the Glaucoma/Myopia OCT Phenotyping Consortium (GMOPC) to build three new 360 subject, study cohorts to improve the OCT detection of optic nerve head (ONH), pNC and pPole structural abnormality in myopia and glaucoma (www.gmopconsortium.org).
figure_13.caption: The composition of each cohort will consist of 60 European Descent, 60 African Descent, 60 Hispanic Ethnicity, 60 Japanese, 60 Chinese and 60 Korean eyes. AL – Axial Length; SE – Spherical Equivalent; D – Diopters; dB – decibel; GLVFL – Glaucomatous Visual Field Loss; VF – Visual Field

figure_14.title: Figure 14. GMOPC OCT data acquisition will occur relative to the FoBMO axis using a next generation Spectralis (Heidelberg Engineering) OCT instrument that includes high-speed eye-tracking, high-speed OCT A-scan acquisition and increased axial data collection to optimize pPole visualization in highly myopic eyes.
figure_14.caption: Both longstanding “Legacy” scan patterns (left) and new “Isotropic Posterior Pole” (pPole) scan patterns (for both structural and angiography analyses) (right) will be obtained on each study eye. (ONH-RC - optic nerve head (ONH) 48 radial and circular B-scans (at three locations) acquired relative to the FoBMO axis, centered on the BMO centroid); (pPoleH - serial horizontal B-scans acquired parallel to the FoBMO axis); (pPoleV – serial vertical b-scans acquired perpendicular to the FoBMO axis.

figure_15.title: Figure 15. ONH neural canal scleral flange remodeling includes “externalization” and “bowing” that underlie myopic ONH staphylomatous degeneration and can be parameterized using OCT parameters complimentary to pNC-SB-SS (manuscripts in preparation).
figure_15.caption: (A1 – C1, left) Representative OCT B-scans from representative non-highly myopic (A1 – top), (B1 – middle) and highly myopic (C1 - bottom) eyes. (A2 - C2) Because the internal boundaries of the depicted tissues are anatomically continuous, the internal boundaries shown are representative. The anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) is defined to be the projection of the anterior pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues. The scleral flange is histologically defined to be the pNC sclera that is “internal” or “medial” to the dural sheath insertion. Current OCT parameterization of the pNC scleral flange (commonly referred to as the “gamma” region) employs a projection of the clinical disc margin rather than segmentation of the OCT-detected scleral flange opening (SFO, yellow circle) to define its inner-most margin. When there is a region of exposed scleral flange tissue internal to the ASCO, the SFO can be manually segmented either “geometrically” when identifiable (Panels B2 and C2) or “estimated” by visually projecting the anterior laminar surface through the neural canal wall (Panel A2). (A3 – C3) The slope of the anterior scleral flange surface (between the ASCO and SFO) can be calculated in a manner that is separate from, but complimentary to, the pNC-SB-SS parameter (Figure 5.

claims.sentence: To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

(A) The clinical “optic disc” (or “papilla”) and “peripapillary” regions are defined relative to the clinical disc margin (Figure 1). (B) We propose that OCT evaluation of the ONH tissues should be organized relative to the OCT-detected neural canal and the Foveal-BMO axis (see Figures 3 and 4).

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

Open in a new tab
Descriptions of Panels A through H are the same for both the healthy control and highly myopic eyes. (A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4).

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42
Figure 4.
FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

Within the 3D point cloud of segmented points from each OCT ONH data set, (Figure 3), Bruch’s membrane and the anterior scleral surface points were interpolated using b-splines. pNC-CT was assessed in microns at six distances (vertical blue dotted lines) from the ASCO, measured within the ASCO reference plane, (horizontal blue dotted line).
To simplify data presentation, we concentrate on pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points (where they approximate the measurement of pNC-SS (see Figure 5).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

ICC values for the sectoral pNC-SB and pNC-CT parameters ranged from moderate to excellent (.51 to 0.99) (mean ± SD 0.92 ± 0.11), however pNC-SB-SS (0- 300 μms) values for the superior-nasal (0.23) and nasal-superior sectors (0.46) (Figure 4) were poor.Highly myopic versus control Comparisons
pNC-SB was increased and pNC-CT was decreased in the highly myopic compared to control eyes and these increases and decreases were greatest in the inferior and inferior temporal quadrant sectors.
Plots of eye-specific, global data versus age for the pNC-SB and CT parameters are reported in Figure 8.

Bold - P ≤ 0.05
Mean sectoral values for all pNC-SB and pNC-CT parameters are reported for control and highly myopic eyes in Figure 9.
Within the control and highly myopic groups, the pCT values in the thickest pNC-CT sectors were significantly thicker than the thickness values in lowest pNC-CT sectors (Figure 9).

For pNC-CT1100, choroidal thickness in the thinnest sectors was significantly thinner in the highly myopic compared to the control eyes.Sectoral pNC-SB is not related to sectoral pNC-CT in the control eyes, but is inversely related to sectoral pNC-CT in the highly myopic eyes. (Figure 10).
Data for the pNC-SB-ASCOD versus pNC-CT 1100 comparison is representative of all comparisons and is reported here and shown in Figure 10.

Maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-SB were increased and maximum and minimum sectoral pNC-CT were decreased within the inferior sectors of the highly myopic with GLVFL compared to the highly myopic without GLVFL eyes (Supplemental Figure 1) but these differences did not achieve statistical significance.

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).
Clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, FoBMO visualization of pNC-SB and pNC-CT data for the healthy control (upper) and highly myopic (lower) eyes shown in Figure 3.

FoBMO orientation of the data is achieved by rotating the photo (8° counter clock-wise above and 10° clockwise below) so that the FoBMO axis, rather than the Acquired Image Frame ((AIF) - Blue outline –Figure 4), establishes the Nasal-Temporal and Superior-Inferior axes (shown for the healthy control eye, above, red dotted lines). (B) pNC-SB-ASCOD data for each eye schematically presented in eye-specific, (left eye above and right eye, below) FoBMO orientation. (C) pNC-SB-SS data for the inner (0-300), middle (300-700) and outer (700-1000) measurement segments presented schematically in FoBMO orientation. (D) Continuously plotted pNC-SB-SS data in FoBMO orientation. (E) and (F) pNC-CT data presented schematically (E) and continuously (F) relative to the FoBMO axis.

Note that while the sectoral differences in pNC-CT data are modest for the control eye (upper) and substantial for the highly myopic eye (lower), by inspection of the sectoral values, the inferior temporal regions demonstrate the greatest amount of pNC-SB and the thinnest pNC-CT for both the control and highly myopic eye.Figure 12.
Figure 11 illustrates how both pNC-SB and pNC-CT can be topographically mapped on the infrared (IR) fundus image acquired at the time of OCT imaging.

However, to know if either eye demonstrates sectoral values that are outside of normative values requires eye- specific structural abnormality detection as shown in Figure 12 is required.Clinically-intuitive, topographically correspondent, myopic and glaucomatous structural abnormality detection relative to the FoBMO axis.

Figure 12 illustrates our conceptual framework for clinically-intuitive, topographically-correspondent, structural abnormality detection in non-highly myopic and highly myopic eyes relative to normative data bases.

A large group of investigators and studies have contributed to the development of topographically-correspondent structural abnormality detection.1,44,105,124-138 An important goal of our paradigm is to detect and characterize ONH and pPole structural abnormality in a topographically correspondent fashion (Figure 12) so as to improve their clinical characterization through the full spectrum of myopia and glaucoma.

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). (C) OCT-radial B-scan from the location depicted by the green line in Panel B. (D) The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening (SFO – yellow dot on left) when present – (see Discussion section and Figure 15) and ends at the posterior scleral canal opening (not shown) which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

(A) A 24-radial B-scan optical coherence tomography (OCT) data set is shown (feint green lines) after acquisition relative to the fovea to BMO centroid (FoBMO) axis (red dotted line – see Figure 4).

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42
Figure 4.
FoBMO image acquisition is illustrated in Figure 14.

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

To simplify data presentation and statistical analyses, we emphasize pNC-CT at the 300, 700 and 1100 μm measurement points where they most closely approximate the measurement of pNC-SB-SS (see Figure 5).Previously reported ONH OCT Parameters.

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).
As is standard in clinical practice, N, T, S and I are assigned without anatomic justification based on the “acquired-image frame” of the photo (blue outline see Figure 4).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). (Right) We suggest that the ONH tissues biomechanically and physiologically include the dural sheath, the pNC portion of the inferior oblique extraocular muscle (EOM) insertion, the posterior ciliary artery insertions (via the dural sheath – not shown), as well as the pNC scleral collagen ring, (not shown) and contained vascular circle of Zinn-Haller, (also not shown).Figure 2.

The “pre-scleral” neural canal extends from Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) (the entrance to the neural canal) to the anterior scleral canal opening (ASCO) and is defined by the choroidal border tissues of Elschnig (Figure 3). ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

Conventional disc photos (Figure 1 left panel) and most OCT imaging are regionalized relative to the acquired image frame (AIF–blue image outline) vertical and horizontal axes (blue dotted lines) which have no anatomic foundation and are influenced by variable head position and cyclotorsion at the time of imaging.

Our own study in 362 non-highly myopic healthy eyes,41 three-dimensionally (3D) characterized pNC-SB within 48 radial B-scans using the two pNC-SB parameters of the present report - one based on the slope of the pNC sclera (pNC-SB-scleral slope (pNC-SB-SS)) (Figure 5) and the other based on ASCO depth relative to a pNC scleral reference plane (pNC-SB-ASCOD) (Figure 6).
Note that since slope is unitless, pNC-SB-SS is a unitless parameter. pNC-SB data is multiplied by 100 to enhance visualization.Figure 6.

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

The majority of studies measuring pNC-CT using OCT have either employed BMO as the reference opening for its regional quantification72-74 or utilize pNC OCT circle scans at varying distances from BMO or BMO centroid to make the measurement.75-77 In our previous description of pNC-CT in 362 healthy non-highly myopic eyes,40 and as it has been done in the current study, pNC-CT was assessed at six distances from the ASCO, measured within an ASCO reference plane (Figure 7).

First, BMO can be difficult to distinguish in highly myopic eyes.78 second, segmenting both the ASCO and BMO in a given eye identifies the location of internally and externally oblique border tissue regions which can complicate the pNC-CT measurement (Figure 7).

To do so, our study utilizes a conceptual framework for clinically evaluating the optic nerve head (ONH) tissues (Figure 1) using optical coherence tomography (OCT).1 We argue that this conceptual framework represents a paradigm change from two dimensionally examining the “clinical disc” as defined by the clinical disc margin to three-dimensionally examining the ONH tissues based on Bruch’s membrane opening (BMO) and the neural canal (Figure 2).

We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically to include the tissues within the neural canal (Figure 2) and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the peri-neural canal (pNC) retina, choroid, and sclera (Figures 2 and 3) as well as the immediate retrobulbar orbital optic nerve (Right). ONH neural canal tissues are contained within the neural canal and ONH pNC tissues are adjacent and peripheral to BMO and the neural canal wall.We define the ONH anatomically and morphologically (Figure 1) to include the tissues within the neural canal and those immediately adjacent to it, namely, the pNC retina, choroid, and sclera, the immediate retrolaminar orbital optic nerve, the dural and pial sheath insertions and the medial portion of the inferior oblique muscle insertion.

It consists of the connective tissue component of the choroidal border tissues which are known histologically as the border tissues of Elschnig.20-22 The scleral portion of the neural canal extends from the ASCO through the scleral flange opening, (when present morphologically - see Discussion and Figure 2), ending at the posterior scleral canal opening which is inconsistently visualized by OCT.

The neural canal expands as it passes through the sclera.16 In Figure 1, vitreal and retrobulbar views of an 8 mm trephined non-human primate ONH tissue specimen illustrate the profound increase in size of the retrobulbar nerve and dural sheath relative to the size of the “clinical disc”.

We use the term pNC to distinguish OCT ONH anatomic terminology, (which we argue should be based on OCT-detected anatomic landmarks) from the traditional clinical terms “optic disc”, “papilla”, and “peripapillary” which being based on the clinical disc margin have no consistent histologic or OCT-detectable anatomic foundation.23,24 Having no consistent anatomic foundation, the clinical disc margin is inconsistently assigned by clinicians25 leading to inaccuracy in the clinical assessment of the rim tissue (Figure 1).24,26 Because the clinical disc margin is also central to the definitions of clinical concepts such as “optic disc tilt” and “torsion” as well as the “gamma”, “delta” and “peripapillary atrophy” zones, it has additionally contributed to the lack of anatomically consistent OCT definitions for these terms.27-29
This OCT paradigm additionally proposes that ONH, pNC, macular and posterior pole (pPole) anatomy should be used to consistently acquire OCT data and regionalize it relative to the Foveal-BMO axis (Figure 4).1,30 The OCT-defined FoBMO axis extends from the OCT-detected BMO centroid to the OCT-detected foveal center.

As such it estimates the location of the histologic temporal raphe.31-34 Using this approach, we and others, have characterized the following anatomic and morphologic targets in large mixed ethnicity35, Japanese36 Brazilian37 and Chinese38 normative data bases: ONH minimum rim width35-38; pNC retinal nerve fiber layer thickness (RNFLT)35-37; anterior lamina cribrosa surface depth39; pNC choroidal thickness (pNC-CT)40; neural canal obliqueness, minimum cross-sectional area (NCMCA) and ASCO/BMO offset19; pNC-scleral bowing (pNC-SB)41; and the thickness of multiple retinal layers within the macula.42

To image each eye, the operator manually identified and marked the fovea in a live B-scan, then centered the imaging field on the ONH, where the 2 BMO points in each of 2 perpendicular ONH radial B-scans were identified.35 These steps established the eye-specific, FoBMO axis, which was used as the reference for the acquisition of all subsequent OCT B-scans (Figure 4).1 The ONH imaging pattern consisted of 24 radial B-scans (15° apart with each B-scan containing 768 A-scans) centered on BMO.

Our methods of OCT image manual segmentation have been described in detail previously.19,35,39,40,42 In brief, raw OCT volumes were exported from the device and imported into a custom 3D visualization and segmentation software (Devers Eye Institute, ATL 3D Suite, Portland, OR).93 ONH and peri-neural canal landmarks (Figures 1 and 2) were manually segmented in each radial B-scan and the ONH was reconstructed 3-dimensionally (Figure 2).
To characterize pNC-SB, two OCT parameters, (pNC-SB-SS) (Figure 5) and pNC-SB - ASCOD, (Figure 6) were employed.

The anterior pNC-scleral surface in each B-scan was fitted with a three-segmented linear model implemented with a non-linear curve-fitting function LSQCURVEFIT in Matlab (Version 7.3.0.267, MathWorks, Natick, MA) which minimized the least square error between fitted and raw values (Figure 5).

Three pNC-SB-SS segments (0-300 μm), (300 to 700 μm), and (700 to 1000 μm), were measured relative to each ASCO point within the ASCO reference plane and projected to the anterior scleral surface (Figure 2).

Slope data were multiplied by 100 for presentation and analysis.pNC-SB-ASCOD.
pNC-SB-ASCOD measured the depth of the ASCO relative to a peripheral scleral reference plane (Figure 6) created by fitting a plane to 48 anterior scleral surface points located 1,700 mm from the ASCO centroid within each radial B-scan (MATLAB version 7.3.0.267). pNC-SB-ASCOD was determined at each segmented ASCO point as the minimum distance to the pNC scleral reference plane (negative when above the plane and positive when below). pNC-SB-ASCOD was defined sectorally as the average depth value of the 4 ASCO points within each 30-degree sector and globally as the average value of all 48 ASCO measurement points.pNC-CT.

Global and 30° sectoral pNC-CT measurements were generated as previously described40 based on the minimum distance between the anterior scleral surface and Bruch’s Membrane within radial segments at 100, 300, 500, 700, 900 and 1100 micron distances from the ASCO (Figure 7).

In this paper, (and the papers that precede it)18,19,41 we identified the ASCO by projecting the immediate pNC scleral surface through the choroidal border tissues to the neural canal boundary (Figure 1).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).

In the present cross-sectional study, we do not include pNC-CT measurements within oblique border tissue regions because the density of the border tissues themselves and the adjacent choroidal septa make the presence of active choroidal vasculature difficult to determine (Figure 7), and because the regional distribution and extent of internally and externally oblique border tissues are not consistent among human eyes.110,111 However, we predict that oblique border tissue regions will be most susceptible to longitudinal pNC-CT thinning because pNC-CT is thinnest in these regions (Figure 7).
